Award.AwardTitle: Exploring Methods for Improving Teachers' Mathematical Quality of Instruction

Directorate.LongName: Direct For Education and Human Resources

Award.AbstractNarration:
The Exploring Methods for Improving Teachers' Mathematical Quality of Instruction (MQI) is an exploratory project at Harvard Graduate School of Education. Researchers are working with 4th and 5th grade teachers to improve their mathematics instruction by experimenting with different ways to implement the MQI model of professional development. The professional development requires teachers to critique and discuss videos of mathematics instruction. The professional development experiences are intentionally aligned with the Mathematical Quality of Instruction (MQI) observation instrument.

The researchers are investigating the impact of several variables on the success of their professional development model as measured by how well teachers can assess videos of mathematics instruction. Researchers are exploring the model by varying the modes of delivery (face-to-face or internet), meeting time (weekly or bi-weekly), facilitator involvement (high or low) and the type of video used (project video or personal video). They are producing case studies using the school group as the unit of analysis.

This research can inform models of professional development by providing more information about various ways that the same model of professional development can be implemented. The use of case studies provides an in depth understanding of the group dynamics and how the variables influence what is learned and observed by teachers of mathematics.

POR.DRECONTENT:
Collaborative analysis of classroom video has proven a promising venue for STEM teacher professional development. Despite progress in this field, two questions remain: the degree to which teachers vs. expert facilitators should lead video-based professional development, and whether teachers should analyze video from their own classrooms or from a video library. This study sought to answer these questions, both to assist in the design of our own mathematics professional development program and to inform scholars and practitioners about effective program features. To do so, we conducted a short (35-hour) professional development program based around a video analysis protocol, the Mathematical Quality of Instruction instrument, systematically varying facilitation level and the source of video for analysis.  

We used proximal outcome measures – teacher reflections on their own and others’ practice – in place of more expensive, distal measures such as observations of classroom instruction and student tests. Results show that participation in the overall program increased teachers’ use of specific types of video analysis techniques. However, only teachers who both self-facilitated discussions and analyzed their own video changed how they reflected on their own lessons. Conversely, teachers in the externally facilitated / video library condition were more likely to identify problems in their delivery of content to students, suggesting this condition led to more critical self-reflection. There were no changes among other proximal outcomes, including the extent to which teachers planned changes to lessons or spontaneously reported difficulties in the lesson.

From these results, we recommend that scholars and practitioners design stronger video-based interventions, ones that capitalize on both the expertise of facilitators and teachers. Our own design will contain a hybrid of external facilitation and teacher-led discussions around videos from their own classrooms.  More information on our video analysis program and this study is available upon request from Mary Beisiegel, beisiegm@science.oregonstate.edu.
